review_title: So Much Potential, So Little Effort
pros:
Benefits such as time off (including very generous holidays off, "winter week" off, and more sick time than you can shake a stick at), health insurance, and flexible schedules (for only some employees and there is confusion/bitterness around who gets this perk and who doesn't) are top notch.
Frequent leftover free food from workshops and seminars
Opportunities to attend organization's workshop and seminars for free. Regularly scheduled lunches with guest lecturers.
Well known organization in the field of education. Great starting point or pit stop for a resume builder.
cons: A tendency to be overly academic and snobbish about it. Upper management is a "good ol boys" club of people who have been there for decades, make all the calls, ignore feedback, and resist change, particularly change that may alter the power structure. Incompetence is rewarded at upper management level (you if refuse to learn how to do a certain task, there will be no consequences and that task will be assigned to a lower level employee who does not get compensated for it). Lower level positions turn overly quickly once people realize this is the set up.

pros:
About three quarters of the staff are truly kind and genuinely interested in each other’s success.  

The onboarding of new hires is thorough, thoughtful and customized to each staff person.

All staff believe in the mission/ there are daily opportunities for inspiration.
cons:
There is rampant unprofessionalism and casualness in the culture as well as a too-many-cooks in the kitchen democratic mentality that gets in the way more often than it’s productive. The culture needs a serious makeover.

Staff who have repeatedly failed on accountability get infinite forgiveness when they fail to follow through.  A portion, but not all, of senior staff have a reputation for berating the staff they oversee, and texting their coworkers at all hours outside of work which goes unchecked.  It is humiliating for support staff to constantly compensate for the bad behavior. The organization suffers from a high turnover rate.  There is an unsettling tradition of distrust of newer staff from the senior staff, which discourages growth and innovation.  There is a history of nepotism -- hiring friends of friends instead of hiring based on qualifications and skills.

It’s an awful paradox for an org that has a mission about compassion, tolerance and understanding, empowering students to be agents of change and peace that it allows staff to be trampled on emotionally and disrespected, in fact, Facing History ignores such behavior.

review_title: Great organization, not much upward mobility
pros: The organization does important work fighting prejudice, racism, and hate through education and there are lots of opportunities to learn about the curriculum as a staff member.
cons: Not much opportunity for career growth.

review_title: Culture could be better, which they know
pros: The mission and the work are important and effective. The outcomes are impressive. And the methodology is world class.
cons: The headquarter office does not understand how to utilize the regional offices and instead often, commonly, works against them. The lack of support for multi-year planning, and lack of commitment by the headquarter leadership to leverage the regional relationships (with educational, civic, and philanthropic partners) is wasteful and counterproductive. The headquarter objectives almost always attempt to drive regional activity, but cannot, because they ignore regional resources and so the constant push-pull of regions waiting for what is promised, but never comes, or the headquarter leadership attempting to drive the national progress, without consultation or integration with fellow colleagues/experts in their own regions is truly wasteful of time, resources, and energy (i.e. you will be exhausted to your bones if you are caught in this fray within a frighteningly short time).

review_title: An organization that needs to embrace change, but can't
pros: Intellectualism is a prized quality at Facing History. The people there are highly educated and hold advanced and terminal degrees from the best higher ed institutions in the world. The organization hires some of the best educational minds out there. The leadership truly believes that they are changing the world one teacher at a time, and the teachers who use the Facing History curriculum in their classroom swear by it. Among educators, this organization has a top-notch reputation.
cons: There are always too many cooks in the kitchen for every decision that needs to be made. Project management is impossible because nobody seems to be held accountable for getting things done. Employee morale is lower than it should be. The leadership is out of touch with the direction  education is moving regarding technology, student/teacher accountability, addressing diversity of learning styles, and overall pragmatism. There is an almost cult-like mentality around the Scope and Sequence (the curriculum model adopted by the organization more than 30 years ago). The leadership micromanages. Several key roles within the organization are held by inept people. The advancement path is murky.

review_title: Great Mission, Seriously Off Track Management
pros:
- The staff who work directly with educators provide a top-notch experience overall, & the organization has an amazing network of inspired & inspiring educators, advisors, partners, & donors. 
- Great mission and tradition
- Salaries are competitive, benefits solid
- Opportunities to learn are many
- It's possible to find wise allies, warm colleagues if you reach out horizontally
cons:
- Senior management at odds with one another, distrustful and secretive
- A few top managers micromanage all significant decisions, and are resentful & dismissive of  skill &  expertise in staff 
- Cycle of paying $ to consultants but not taking their advice, hiring staff with great backgrounds but refusing to let them have any decision-making ability, lead to revolving door
- Discrepancy between  mission and leaders' lack of respect towards anyone who does not come from their narrow  same-friends background. 
- No joke, if you're used to being successful & valued at other jobs and go through an exciting interview process (in which leaders show best side), if you come here you will be shocked at how quickly and thoroughly you will end up being made small.

review_title: There could not be a more timely organization right now to work for!
pros: Under the new leadership of Roger Brooks, this organization has been transforming itself to have a greater impact and to build a model workplace. A new ethos based on quality, accountability, civility and mutual respect has taken root. A diversity & inclusion initiative is underway and showing real results. Some of the best people around work here and if you can land a job, you will be very satisfied with the quality of the work, the mission, and kindness of the people.
cons: Some practices from the past made meetings long, decisions hard to get, and left some people in management who were not effective and in some cases not pleasant to work with. Fortunately, the new leadership has strongly addressed each of these issues over the past 2 years and made some of the hard decisions that needed to be made. An all-staff survey was listened to and things are on the right path.

pros: Very competitive salary and benefits, particularly for a nonprofit. Many employees have a lot of passion for their work. New CEO has brought needed structure and organization.
cons: The organization is very top-heavy and is not run in accordance with the mission. Most employee's voices and ideas are not welcomed and if you speak up for yourself there can be repercussions. Very clique-ish. Lack of diversity. Upper management is wildly overpaid. In general, managers do not make their employee's success a priority and there is very little tolerance for mistakes. Many staff members are lifers and are unable to advance their thinking or break old, dysfunctional patterns. If you are the type of person who likes to keep your head down and work, it might be good fit. If you are vocal, value collaboration, or want to innovate, you will not thrive here.

pros: The mission of the organization and the commitment of the staff to that mission  are unparalleled. The staff is caring, empathic, committed to the organization's values, smart, and forward thinking.  The company has just completed a comprehensive strategic planning process which will steer exciting and innovative growth and new directions for the next 5 years.  New staff, with extensive industry experience in key strategic areas, have joined the company and others are being recruited to help realize company growth goals.
cons: The physical working space is cramped (the company is housed in a former school building) and the parking is challenging at times..  The good news is that space planning is underway.

review_title: People make choices, choices make history
pros: FHAO vets its candidates for employment well - fairly and transparently.  Supervisors, managers, and directors are by and large former teachers.  I was a "Facing History Teacher" for 10 years before I joined the staff.  I’d recommend to anyone applying, go to a Facing History event or take online workshop before you apply. Make sure you find their mission one you really believe.
cons: As is true in any educational consultancy, there are occasional push backs, debate, and differences expressed. HR leaders are eager to help and to smooth crises.  I love the people.

pros: The mission and passion of the employees.
cons: Management is purposely writing positive reviews to balance the negative ones on this site. This is an activity they began when I was an employee there a few years ago.  Look closely at these reviews--you will be able to tell which ones are authentic and which ones have been carefully crafted. It is activities like this that show the darker side of Facing History, which presents a rosy picture of itself to the outside instead of owning it's workplace issues and trying to resolve them in positive and proactive ways.

pros: Great mission. Teachers love the curriculum resources and training that Facing History offers. cons: Negativity among employees. More backstabbing and complaining than any place that I've worked. Not much of a "team" environment. Overcrowded work space in old building with bad HVAC.

review_title: Be weary of glowing reviews here.
pros:
Incredible mission that is consistently validated by national and world events. There are many people here who are compassionate, intelligent, and motivated by making a difference in the world. There's a lot of momentum happening and if you come in with resilience and persistence, you can find a niche here, but it's very dependent on the team you're on. Benefits are excellent and hard to find. 

While it was often very overwhelming due to the low staffing in creative roles, there's often never a slow moment so you're hoping between so many types of projects which can provide a wide range of experiences.
cons:
Please be weary of overwhelmingly positive reviews; it should be a red flag anywhere on reviews like this. These obviously biased and were written to balance the critical reviews here.

There's a weird incongruence with the external face of the organization versus what happens internally. High staff turnover has been an issue for a long time, especially in regions. Career support is practically non-existent for creative roles since the company is still struggling to value those roles–which is fairly common in non-profits, but just be aware that it's a an uphill battle always.

Chaotic nature of management can be extremely draining and depressive for younger staff who come in with a lot of initiative and energy to create change. Infighting between senior staff (too many cooks in the kitchen) and not a lot of trust between them creates a combative atmosphere that's hard to succeed in, or push projects through successfully. Poor communication and planning plague many initiatives and projects and stunt the organization's potential to be truly exceptional. 

I know that things will eventually stabilize, but it has been turbulent my entire time at the organization.

pros: Such a terrific mission that it's amazing it's not just baked into our educational system already.
cons: There is a "fresh-blood-will-sort-out-this-mess" approach to management that is a real achilles heal for the organization.

review_title: An organization that really needs to face itself
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Flexible schedule at times, great virtual training from the Boston office and great benefits.
cons: Considering that it is a non-profit organization with a great mission, they do not value diversity in employment. Employees of color were treated like "the help" and not given a voice to make suggestions or recommendations to streamline processes. Supervisors were condescending and liked to micromanage, but if you tell them that you are not comfortable with it expect to be treated even worse.

review_title: A work environment that doesn't practice what it preaches
pros: Pay is above average for this sector and the retirement plan is good. There are a handful of people who are genuinely passionate about making positive change in the world.
cons:
Facing History is very stuck in its ways and the leadership is delusional about how to frame what the organization does and become an established, respected brand that is recognized outside of its tiny niche. 

The organization shuns common-sense business practices and is incapable of changing with trends in technology and marketing. The people who work here are made to feel very self-aware of their shortcomings and it causes a fear-based culture where no one wants to take ownership over decisions. People are very quick to pass off blame even when there are no accusations being made. 

There are tons of unproductive meetings, and all of the "important" ones are lead by a gossipy, all-talk trio who essentially run the place and like to have the same ego-boosting conversations every week (because no one understood what they covered the week before...) It's certainly not a rewarding work environment for those who care about making measurable improvements and working with actual innovators and do-ers - which, frustratingly, is exactly what Facing History thinks they are. 

The organization is full of this sort of irony: with a mission that encourages standing up against bias and bullying, Facing History is unfortunately full of people who turn up their noses at others, ice people out, and regularly publicly embarrass or gang up on each other. And to anyone under the age of 30- good luck. As soon as you show any real signs of confidence or growth, you'll be subtly cut down to size, belittled daily, made the butt of jokes of meetings, and only once you've gotten some space from the place will you realize how much you actually know and can offer... there's a reason that young people don't hang around!

review_title: A great time to work at Facing History
pros:
Mission is so important, especially in the times we are living in. I really believe we make a difference in the lives of teachers and their students. 
Fun, passionate, hard-working colleagues (at least on my team) who really want to make this a great place to work.
Intellectual atmosphere - if you are a life-long learner, this is a place for you! Hard not to watch or read the news and constantly be having "Facing History" moments. Lots of opportunities to learn about our content areas and work even if you aren't on the program team. 
Amazing benefits package and flexibility given to staff I have never witnessed anywhere else.
Organization is on a solid financial footing and growth path. New strategic plan about to launch which invited and had the participation of many staff and board. Key leadership being hired in areas of marketing and technology and fundraising.
cons:
The headquarters office is actually in an old Catholic school building which is fitting for the education mission but it's not the best suited space for an office of over 100 people.  Management recently hired a space planner but not sure that will alleviate all the issues that come with an old building. Still, having free parking with this property in the Boston area, is a great perk that offsets the temperature and space issues. 
The old  culture was one that often avoided confrontation which allowed underperformers to linger on for years without consequences. There has been a shift towards accountability and taking needed actions but still more work has to be done. Performance management and compensation administration aren't aligned yet, but leadership is starting to take steps. Change can still be slow...but I think that's from a combination of not wanting to upset staff too much and not being more decisive.

review_title: I felt used and belittled like an animal
pros:
The majority of staff are incredibly empathetic, passionate, dedicated colleagues who embody the company mission. They're pleasant and worldly, and with the headquarters housing 100 people, lunch in the kitchen or passing each other in the halls is always social and warm. Whatever you're interested in, someone will have either done it, gone there, or studied it. 

There's often free food! Since the organization is so well-off financially, there's usually catering for all sorts of events, i.e UpperCrust Pizza for summer interns, and lox, capers, cream cheese on tasty bagels. The benefits are very good, health, dental, retirement, etc. 

You get 3 weeks of vacation and a complimentary Winter week, so that's 4 weeks (1 month!) paid. There is a lively energy, permeating down from the Executive Director, which makes everyone act faster.

If you're a history buff and/or love books, the shelves and library collection will keep you learning and curious. Plus, books everywhere is aesthetically appeasing (to some).
cons:
Disorganization and chaos, exemplified from papers everywhere to everyone stepping on each others' toes while some tasks just never get done as it's assumed someone else will take care of it. 

Some staff are overworked, and while they are entitled to vacation, are still called/emailed and don't have proper replacement staff to cover them-- so sometimes they come in during "vacation" just to prevent chaos for when they return. Sometimes employees are given projects at the end of the day. Sometimes it's expected you reply at 9pm in the evening and/or weekends. 

Employee performance reviews are often laundry lists of mistakes. The culture is - Do Not Make A Mistake, or expect to be scolded and your mistake added to the list. 

Unless you're entering as a Project Manager or higher, the power is at the top, and they've decided there will be no career development or growth opportunity. Most people with Bachelor's degrees leave after a year or two. I don't know which came first: high turn-over leading to senior management deciding not to invest in growth opportunity since employees will leave anyway, OR, senior staff deciding first to not provide growth, which then resulted in the younger people dropping like flies?
